pullRequest.body:
Three lemmas about Quadratic maps applied to:

- A finite sum
- A `linearCombination`
- The representation of an element wrt a basis

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
CC: @eric-wieser
@eric-wieser did you have any further thoughts about this PR please?
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Can you edit the PR description? Right now it is extremely inaccurate (in fact it seems to be 100% false).

I still look at these theorems and think "are these ghastly-looking results ever going to be useful"? Still, I guess there is no harm in adding more theorems?

I believe they are ghastly-looking solely because we don't have a nice way to sum over several unordered indices. We know how to sum over `i, j`, how to sum over `i, j, i < j`, but not really how to sum over `{i, j}, i ≠ j`.
@eric-wieser @YaelDillies I think I've got as far as I can with this if you're able to take another look please?

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21835~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Thanks!

maintainer delegate

Maybe
```suggestion
    Q x = (bm.repr x).sum fun i r => (r * r) • Q (bm i) +
```
Done.
Can we add a `QuadraticMap.map_finsupp_sum` lemma and use it here?
Done, thanks @eric-wieser . That works very nicely.
I'd be inclined to introduce a `Finsupp.sym2OffDiag` here, so that this theorem holds without `LinearOrder ι`
Would that be something of the form `def Finsupp.sym2OffDiag (f : ι →₀ R) : Finset (ι × ι) := sorry`?

Perhaps
```
noncomputable instance : DecidablePred fun (s : Sym2 ι) ↦ ¬s.IsDiag := Classical.decPred _

noncomputable def Finsupp.sym2OffDiag (f : ι →₀ R) : Finset (Sym2 ι) := 
  f.support.sym2.filter (fun ij => ¬ ij.IsDiag) 
```

?

Then the statement would be:
```
noncomputable instance : DecidableEq ι := by exact Classical.typeDecidableEq ι

open Finsupp in
theorem map_finsupp_sum (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (f : ι →₀ R) (g : ι → R → M) :
    Q (f.sum g) = (f.sum fun i r => Q (g i r)) +
    ∑ ij ∈ f.sym2OffDiag,
    (Sym2.lift ⟨fun i j => (polar Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), fun _ _ => polar_comm _ _ _⟩) ij := by
  rw [sum, QuadraticMap.map_sum]
  apply congrArg (HAdd.hAdd _)
  sorry
```

These things both look the same to me... but not to mathlib:
```
⊢ ∑ ij ∈ Finset.filter (fun ij ↦ ¬ij.IsDiag) f.support.sym2,
    Sym2.lift ⟨fun i j ↦ polar (⇑Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), ⋯⟩ ij =
  ∑ ij ∈ Finset.filter (fun ij ↦ ¬ij.IsDiag) f.support.sym2,
    Sym2.lift ⟨fun i j ↦ polar (⇑Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), ⋯⟩ ij
```
I strongly recommend not shooting yourself in the foot with `noncomputable instance : DecidableEq ι := by exact Classical.typeDecidableEq ι`

> Would that be something of the form `def Finsupp.sym2OffDiag (f : ι →₀ R) : Finset (ι × ι) := sorry?`

No, I think I'm actually suggesting something more like
```
/-- All the products of pairs of elements in `f`. -/
noncomputable def Finsupp.sym2Mul [CommMonoidWithZero R] (f : ι →₀ R) : Sym2 ι →₀ R :=
  .onFinset
    f.support.sym2
    (Sym2.lift ⟨fun i j => f i * f j, fun _ _ => mul_comm _ _⟩)
    (Sym2.ind <| by aesop)
```

@eric-wieser presumably I want to sum over something like:
```
f.sym2Mul.support.filter (fun t => ¬ t.IsDiag)
```
But this gives me:
```
failed to synthesize
  DecidablePred fun t ↦ ¬t.IsDiag
```
Presumably
```
noncomputable instance : DecidablePred fun (t : Sym2 ι) ↦ ¬t.IsDiag := Classical.decPred _
```
isn't the correct solution?
I guess I need `[DecidableEq ι]`?

Okay, how about:
```
variable {ι R M N}

variable [CommRing R] [AddCommGroup M] [AddCommGroup N] [Module R M] [Module R N] [DecidableEq ι]

open Finsupp in
theorem map_finsupp_sum (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (f : ι →₀ R) (g : ι → R → M) :
    Q (f.sum g) = (f.sum fun i r => Q (g i r)) +
    ∑ p ∈ f.support.sym2 with ¬ p.IsDiag,
      Sym2.lift
        ⟨fun i j => (polar Q) (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), fun i j => by simp only [polar_comm]⟩ p := by
  rw [sum, QuadraticMap.map_sum]
  exact congrArg (HAdd.hAdd _) rfl
```

```suggestion
theorem map_finsuppSum (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (f : ι →₀ R) (g : ι → R → M) :
```
to match the naming convention

The linear version of this result is `map_finsupp_sum` https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/6ac68693d219f89dcb242e9565245f1fbe108953/Mathlib/Algebra/BigOperators/Finsupp.lean#L198 @eric-wieser points out that the names should match the linear equivalents.

Similarly,
```suggestion
theorem map_finsuppLinearCombination (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) {g : ι → M} (l : ι →₀ R) :
```
or
```suggestion
theorem map_linearCombination (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) {g : ι → M} (l : ι →₀ R) :
```

```suggestion
        ⟨fun i j => bm.repr x i • bm.repr x j • polar Q (bm i) (bm j), fun i j => by
```

```suggestion
lemma toBilin_symm_eq_polarBilin (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (bm : Basis ι R M) :
    Q.toBilin bm + (Q.toBilin bm).flip = polarBilin Q := by
```
and is `_symm` a name for `something + something.flip`?
I was thinking of it as being symmetrised (c.f. `LinearMap.IsSymm` in the case of forms).

```suggestion
    Q (f.sum g) = f.sum (fun i r => Q (g i r)) +
```

```suggestion
      ∑ p ∈ s.offDiag with p.1 < p.2,
```

```suggestion
        bm.repr x p.1 • bm.repr y p.2 • (B + B.flip) (bm p.1) (bm p.2) := by
```

```suggestion
        ⟨fun i j => l i • l j • polar Q (g i) (g j), fun i j => by
```

```suggestion
        rw [toQuadraticMap_toBilin Q]
```
same thing below twice
The rest of this PR compiles fine without these theorems, which seem to be a real mouthful. Are you sure we need them?
They don't belong in this PR, so I've split them out into a separate PR #21138. Not sure yet if they're actually useful. Possibly more a case of me thinking aloud.
Looks like you kept exactly the lemmas Kevin was suggesting you get rid of 😆

To my mind the lemmas left in this PR are the useful ones (e.g. if two quadratic maps agree on the basis and their polars evaluated at pairs of basis elements agree then they must be equal) and the other PR has the less useful lemmas.

```suggestion
        bm.repr x i • bm.repr y i • B (bm i) (bm i) +
```

```suggestion
```
These don't seem to be needed.

```suggestion
        ⟨fun i j => polar Q (g i (f i)) (g j (f j)), fun i j => by simp only [polar_comm]⟩ p := by
```

```suggestion
    Q x = (bm.repr x).sum (fun i r => (r * r) • Q (bm i)) +
```
Do we have this theorem for `LinearMap`? I would expect we do, and if so we should try to make the naming match.
The bilinear map version is `LinearMap.sum_repr_mul_repr_mul` and the bilinear form version is `LinearMap.BilinForm.sum_repr_mul_repr_mul`
So something like `QuadraticMap.sum_repl_sq_add_sum_repl_mul_polar` with the `Q x` on the RHS?
The linear equivalent is `Finsupp.apply_linearCombination`.
I think this lemma would be much better if the RHS could somehow be expressed as a (pair of) linear combinations as well. I believe the first term is `linearCombination (l * l) (fun i => Q (g i))`.
`linearCombination R (Q ∘ g) (l * l)` - but the proof is then a little trickier.
@eric-wieser I've made that change - which also brings the statement closer to `Finsupp.apply_linearCombination`.

typos:
```suggestion
-- c.f. `LinearMap.sum_repr_mul_repr_mul`
open Finsupp in
theorem sum_repr_sq_add_sum_repr_mul_polar (Q : QuadraticMap R M N) (bm : Basis ι R M) (x : M) :
```
Could you add a copy of all three lemmas proved with `map_sum'` as well, without the `IsDiag` condition?

I assume something like:
```
lemma testsum (f : ι →  ι → N) (hf : ∀ (a₁ a₂ : ι), f a₁ a₂ = f a₂ a₁) (s : Finset ι) :
    ∑ p ∈ s.sym2 with p.IsDiag,p.lift ⟨f, hf⟩ = ∑ i ∈ s, f i i := sorry
```
must be true, but I can't see how to prove it?

```suggestion
      ∑ p ∈ f.support.sym2,
```

I think inheriting a `*` from a `smul` in this way is not an established pattern in mathlib. This would maybe be a _little_ less objectionable if it used `HSMul`, but fundamentally the heterogenous classes create nasty diamond issues (which I touch on briefly in [Section 4.8](https://eric-wieser.github.io/thesis/eric-wieser-thesis.pdf#page=63) of my thesis.
Presumably I should make it a `def` instead? https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18578/files#diff-b2e63ded24baf2b6dbf29bf1c8d5ff01b0db9b4201ce0726503848038e25b241R30
Can this be a separate PR?
Done  #21835

Isn't it true as
```suggestion
lemma support_mul_subset_left {f g : α →₀ β} :
    (f * g).support ⊆ f.support := fun x hx => by
```
and can you prove it from `Function.support_mul_subset_left`?
Yes, then `support_mul` can be recovered from `support_mul_subset_left` and `support_mul_subset_right`.
Can you keep imports alphabetically?
Can you make this a separate PR?
Do you need this new class? Do you care about an example which is not a `CommMonoidWithZero`?
No, thanks, `CommMonoidWithZero` is perfect. (I had `CommSemiring` before which felt too specific.)

```suggestion
import Mathlib.Algebra.BigOperators.Sym
import Mathlib.Data.Finsupp.Pointwise
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Finsupp.Sym2
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.QuadraticForm.Basic
```

```suggestion
lemma mul_mk {M} [CommMagma M] (xy : M × M) :
```
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18578/commits/b4f9718abaed5100ea67a5ae73ae4f950d78be05

I still look at these theorems and think "are these ghastly-looking results ever going to be useful"? Still, I guess there is no harm in adding more theorems?

I believe they are ghastly-looking solely because we don't have a nice way to sum over several unordered indices. We know how to sum over `i, j`, how to sum over `i, j, i < j`, but not really how to sum over `{i, j}, i ≠ j`.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#21835~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
